 SRI LANKA STAFF APPRAISAL REPORT ENVIRONMENTAL ACTION 1 PROJECT 1. INTRODUCTION 1.1 Sri Lanka has a rich and varied natural resource base, a basic network of economic infrastructure and one of the best sets of social indicators in the developing world with an adult literacy rate of almost 90%. With these assets, Sri Lanka has the potential to match the economic performance of the newly industrialized countries (NICs) of East Asia. In 1989, the Government of Sri Lanka (GOSL) reformed its economic policies. These reforms have led to a significant improvement in economic performance, a surge in private sector investment, and rapid growth in labor-intensive manufactured exports. As industrialization and tourism move forward, it is important that Sri Lanka takes measures to ensure that further growth would not be gained at the expense of the environment or that environmental problems do not hinder the achievement of growth targets. There is a particular need for policy and institutional changes to promote efficient and more sustainable economic growth that explicitly takes environmental factors into consideration. The proposed project is designed to help GOSL meet this need. 1.2 GOSL has taken initial steps to address environmental issues. On the institutional front, it established the Central Environment Authority (CEA) under the National Environmental Act (the Act) in 1980. The Act gives a policy mandate to CEA, and in 1990 it also established the Environment Division (ED) within the then Ministry of Environment and Parliamentary Affairs (MEPA) as the focal entity for environmental policy, a role yet to be effectively assumed. Sri Lanka was also one of the first developing countries to prepare a National Environmental Action Plan (NEAP 1992-96). This was updated in 1994 (NEAP 1995-98) (paras. 2.32-2.35). Finally, GOSL is now drafting new legislation, more comprehensive in scope, in order to place the environment even higher on the national agenda. Despite these initial steps, Sri Lanka remains confronted by serious environmental problems. Chief among these are land degradation and the continuous threat to forest and other vulnerable ecosystems from shifting cultivation, as well as air, water, and soil pollution caused by industrialization and tourism. Several donor agencies, including the Bank, have been assisting GOSL in tackling some of these problems. 1.3 GOSL, in collaboration with the Bank and with financial support from the Royal Norwegian Government, identified and prepared the Environmental Action 1 Project (EA1P). The Bank, while acting as executing agency of a Project Preparation Trust Fund, engaged a consultant team that produced the project preparation report (Sri Lanka Environmental Action 1 Project Preparation Report, July 1, 1994). This staff appraisal report is based on the preparation report and on the updated NEAP. The proposed project is the first phase of a long-term effort to assist GOSL in environmental management. Thc emphasis in this first phase is on strengthening the institutional and policy framework for environmental management within which the Bank and other donors would provide assistance in the environmental sector.
 2 2. ENVIRONMENTAL CONTEXT A. ENVIRONMENTAL RESOURCES AND ISSUES 2.1 The following paragraphs give an overview of Sri Lanka's natural resource base and the nature of environmental problems in each area: 2.2 Land Resources. Of Sri Lanka's 6.5 million ha, 2.2 million ha are under permanent cultivation and 1.1 million ha are under shifting (chena) cultivation. About 73% of cultivated land is under smallholdings. The major agricultural systems include irrigated croplands of rice and other food crops for domestic consumption, mainly centered on 12,000 small anicuts or village tanks in the dry zone; comparatively recent large-scale irrigation development projects, the largest of which are on the Mahaweli River; about 800,000 ha of large, but declining, privately-owned, export-oriented tree crop plantations on the 30-60Â° slopes of the central hill country; and chena cultivation practiced by 250,000 families. Of the total irrigated area, 235,000 ha consists of minor schemes (<80 ha), 255,000 ha of medium schemes (80- 600 ha), and 45,000 ha of major schemes (>600 ha). Closed canopy of natural forests covers 1.33 million ha or 20.2% of the land area. This represents a rapid decline from 44% cover in 1956 and 70-80% in 1900. Over 95% of the forests are state-owned. 2.3 Land degradation is perhaps the most critical environmental problem affecting Sri Lanka's future development. It includes both the degradation of soils through sheet and gully erosion and declining structure and fertility, and degradation of vegetation through deforestation, shifting cultivation, and overuse. The two problems are interrelated and are mostly due to policy failures such as the lack of long- term leases of state-owned land to farmers and the absence of transferable farmer user rights both of which discourage spontaneous investments in sustainable production and contribute to land degradation. Soil erosion leads not only to crop losses but also to negative impacts on hydropower dams and reservoirs, irrigation and water supply infrastructure, and fisheries. Recent studies show that soil erosion in the mid- country is more than 100 tons/ha per annum. The most severe erosion occurs in tobacco lands and neglected tea lands of smallholders. Some reports indicate over 300-400 tons/ha/year soil loss on such lands. In the dry and intermediate zones, more than a million ha are subjected to shifting cultivation that remains one of the principal activities of the majority of the population. Shifting cultivation depletes soil fertility and causes weed infestation, soil erosion, and decline in crop yields. Sri Lanka has one of the highest deforestation rates in the world at 4%. Deforestation has been most severe in the dry zone, and species-rich lowland rain forests are limited to less than 10% of the total forest area. Many remaining natural forests have been seriously degraded, leading to reduced biodiversity. 2.4 Until now, GOSL has not paid much attention to tackling land degradation on a holistic and comprehensive basis involving a watershed approach. Although some initiatives have started recently on an experimental basis, comprehensive strategies and programs to address these issues are several years away. On the basis of the experiences and research in Sri Lanka and similar agroecological zones in Asia, it is possible to design pilot programs using technologies to address the main degradation problems based on the watershed approach. Technologies can be grouped into water and soil conservation technologies such as mulching, construction of stone terraces, and the use of vegetative hedges, and biomass enhancing technologies such as farm forestry and private or community woodlots. The pilot land management component of this project would address the issue of land degradation and test and develop on a watershed basis suitable site-specific technologies, taking account of gradient and soil characteristics for minimizing the extent of land degradation (paras. 3.19-3.24). The pilot thus would help increase agricultural productivity as well as reduce the risk of erosion and its associated on-farm and off-farm impacts. 2.5 Water Resources. More than 100 rivers flow in a radial pattern from the island's central mountains to the sea. Twelve rivers account for 75% of total river discharge, and about half of this flows
 3 through the wet zone. The principal exception is the Mahaweli River, the country's largest, which flows in a northeastern direction through the dry zone to the sea. Most of the country's surface water is used for irrigation, which is provided to about 68% of the total cultivated land, and electricity generation. Hydropower provides 90% of Sri Lanka's current electricity needs, but there is little potential for further large-scale hydropower developments (see para. 2.12). Annual renewable water resources amount to about 5,600 m3 per capita. Only 15% of this total is used, but of this, the greater part (96%) is consuned by agriculture, with 2% used by industry and 2% for domestic purposes. The only area with a water surplus is the western wet zone, and the most acute deficit areas are in the northwest and southeast dry zones. The Asian Development Bank (ADB) is assisting GOSL with preparation of a comprehensive water resource management plan and is strengthening institutional capacity in water resource management. 2.6 Groundwater can provide supplementary irrigation in many areas of the dry zone, except the northern districts. Groundwater is also increasingly used as source of potable water supplies, especially in small towns and rural areas. Similarly, larger urban areas and industrial enterprises are growing users of this water source. Available data show, however, that this development is occurring without considering the resource availability, its renewability, and effects of exploitation on the local ecology. 2.7 The emerging problems relating to water include soil salinity and water logging, deterioration of water quality, emergence of health issues, and depletion of ground water resources. Soil salinity and water logging are major concerns in recently developed irrigation projects where drainage of irrigated lands receives insufficient attention. More than one-third of the population is using unprotected wells, rivers, and tanks and does not have access to safe drinking water. Thus, the incidence of water-related illnesses is very high. The greatest threat to the groundwater supply is in the Jaffna Peninsula, which is dependent on this source for agriculture and human consumption. Groundwater is obtained from caverns that are usually connected to the sea, so that fresh water is confined to the top portion. A good part of the fresh water used for agriculture goes back into these groundwater reservoirs. Therefore, fertilizers and pesticides can pollute this supply. Investigations have already shown considerable aquifer contamination by nitrates, especially in the Kalpitiya and the Jaffna Peninsula. 2.8 Wildlife and Biodiversity. Sri Lanka's biological diversity is of global significance, and it has greater biodiversity per unit area than any other country in Asia. Its wildlife includes 628 known species of terrestrial vertebrates, 84 species of mammals, 379 birds, 32 amphibians, 133 reptiles, and at least 59 species of freshwater fish. Most of the endemic (unique) animal and plant species inhabit the rain forests of the wet zone. Although over 12% of the land has been set aside for conservation in an extensive system of protected areas, most of the relatively large reserves are in the dry zone and not in the wet southwest region where plant and animal diversity and endemism are most significant. Biodiversity is under threat in Sri Lanka primarily from the progressive reduction in its natural forests and other ecosystems such as the wetlands and the mangroves and the selective exploitation of species (particularly for timber). Several donor agencies such as the Norwegian Agency for Development Cooperation (NORAD), the United States Agency for International Development (USAID), the Netherlands, and the United Nations Development Program/Food and Agricultural Organization (UNDP/FAO) are assisting GOSL in a number of biodiversity/wildlife conservation projects, including wetlands. 2.9 Coastal and Marine Resources. Several hundred miles of coral reefs; 120,000 ha of brackish water lagoons, estuaries, and mangrove swamps; and about 140,000 ha of freshwater tanks and reservoirs provide the basis for productive marine and inshore fisheries. The vast majority of the fish catch (85%) comes from marine sources-about 183,000 tons annually. Although fishing contributes only 2% of GDP, fish is the major source of animal protein in the Sri Lankan diet and fishing supports about 500,000 people. The coastal environment, however, is being seriously degraded by various forms of pollution, silt deposition, erosion compounded by sand and coral mining, conversion to tourist facilities, and the loss of mangroves.
 4. 2.10 The key environmental issues in the coastal zones are loss of habitats and nursery grounds; overexploitation of coastal resources including fish, sand, and coral limestone; and marine pollution causing, inter alia, reduced growth rates for coral reefs and other living organisms in the marine environment, health hazards for recreational users of polluted waters, and reduced fish production. The prognosis for the condition of the coastal environment in Sri Lanka by the end of the century is bleak if the current trends of environmental deterioration continue at the present rates. 2.11 Urban and Industrial Pollution. Urbanization and industrialization have occurred virtually without enforcement of regulatory measures. Unregulated industries have exploited underpriced air, water, and land; and unchecked urbanization has spread haphazardly, outstripping adequate infrastructure. Pollution of the urban and industrial sectors has an impact on the aquatic environment. Sri Lanka also faces enormous problems with the special requirements for the disposal of hospital, industrial, and other forms of toxic waste, much of which is expected to increase with continued economic development. Because of the low level of treatment of municipal and industrial wastewater, the receiving waters are considerably polluted. The Kelani River receives untreated effluent from 21 industries and untreated sewage of 1.6 million people living in metropolitan areas. The Colombo Environmental Improvement Project (CEIP) addresses this issue and includes an industrial liquid waste component and a clean settlement program.' Remedial measures to these problems are also taken under the Bank- supported Metropolitan Environmental Improvement Program (MEIP), and pollution reduction projects supported by USAID, the United Nations Industrial Development Organization, and the Netherlands government. 2.12 Energy Sources. The primary energy sources in Sri Lanka include biomass (72%), hydroelectricity (10%), and petroleum (18%). Up to now, Sri Lanka has suffered little environmental damage from energy production and use. Hydro electricity dominates the present power system, and the principal environmental issue that the power sector has had to deal with in the past has been the relocation and resettlement of people displaced by reservoirs. This is changing as the system gradually shifts toward an increasing number of thermal plants. A case study of Sri Lanka2 provides an assessment of a wide range of policy options, including representative demand-side management measures, renewable energy options (such as wind power), and clean coal technologies. The case study is the beginning of a long-term effort to integrate environmental considerations into energy sector planning in Sri Lanka. The Study of Linkages Between Macroeconomic Policies and the Environment in Sri Lanka complements the above assessment (para. 2.36). 2.13 Mineral Resources. Sri Lanka is well endowed with mineral resources. The country's most important minerals are gems that account for about 5% of export earnings. The mining industry can be broadly classified into two categories: artisanal mining and large-scale organized mechanized mining. Gem mining contributes to land degradation, especially in selected localities. The general environmental issues associated with the mining industry include destruction of the vegetative cover and loss of agricultural production, increased occurrence and intensity of floods, increased incidence of vector-borne diseases, and increased coastal erosion. B. MARKET AND POLICY FAILURES 2.14 Market and policy failures result in natural resources not being costed at their true value, thus leading to their inefficient allocation and use and their subsequent degradation. This is true in many developing countries including Sri Lanka, where several conditions for the efficient functioning of markets are lacking, and many natural resource services function outside the marketplace. There is often a wide divergence between the private and social costs of using natural resources. When farmers crop I Sri Lanka. Colombo Environmental Improvement Project (1995). For example, increased water run off from the cropped land or over grazed pasture would cause erosion and increased silting of downstream reservoirs, as well as increased flooding and agricultural and urban damage. Again, the market does not put a value on the environmental services of woodlands, and decisions to cut trees are made without considering the value of these important environmental services. The negative externalities resulting from activities such as deforestation, rangeland degradation, siltation of reservoirs, loss of wildlife habitats, and hydrological imbalance due to the activities of peoples in and around their farms underscore the need for government intervention based on a sustainable resource management strategy. Policies should be put in place to reflect the true opportunity costs of the resource base. Such intervention should take the form of providing incentives/disincentives for adoption of sustainable resource management techniques in achieving increased productivity of resources, education, training, and advice on sustainable and environmentally sound resource management techniques and practices to raise incomes. 2.15 Policy studies undertaken during project preparation identified the range of economy-wide and sectoral policies that have a negative impact (direct or indirect) on the environment and concluded that most of the causes of priority environmental problems can be attributed, in part, to the existing structure of incentives/disincentives (see Annex 8). Based on the findings of the studies, a policy reform agenda conducive to sound environmental management was formulated and included in the updated NEAP (para. 2.32). The wide range of policy issues covered by Sri Lanka's NEAP could be grouped into: (i) issues related to environmental institutions (e.g., current government policies do not include a clear determination of public/private sector roles in environmental management); and (ii) issues that underlie the incentive structure leading to specific environmental problems. The latter issues are, in general, of a sectoral or a microeconomic nature and are generally caused by the underpricing of natural resources with respect to access (leading mainly to agricultural land degradation, deforestation, over fishing, and over mining) or services (leading to pollution by untreated waste disposal, etc.). In some areas, however, analyses are needed to define the exact linkages between the sector and economy-wide policies and the environment (para. 2.36). As important as timely action to address these issues is the need to develop and maintain a capacity for establishing linkages between economic policy and the environment. As a follow up to the above policy studies, a Policy Letter was submitted to IDA on September 1, 1995, and an Action Plan that identifies major environmental policy actions was discussed with GOSL as part of the project (para. 3.13). C. INSTITUTIONAL FAILURES 2.16 Most national environmental strategies and action plans identify institutional weaknesses as a vital factor contributing to the perpetuation of environmental degradation. This is certainly true in Sri Lanka where unclear definition of institutional responsibilities and weak implementation capacity have led to weak environmental management. Project preparatory work revealed that policy formulation, program implementation, enforcement and monitoring are not effectively performed by the various government institutions (paras. 2.19-2.29). There is a lack of clarity of mandates and coordination mechanisms amongst government entities as well as a shortage of well-trained environmental staff in the Ministry of Transport, Environment and Women's Affairs' (MTEWA) ED, CEA, and other line and local entities. One reason for the confusion has been the changing mandates of CEA with regard to policy formulation. While the proposed new environmental legislation would clarify these roles, assistance would be needed to ensure that the new institutional set-up is effective. The shortage of adequate staff resources is exacerbated by a high rate of staff turnover and difficulty in filling vacancies with well-trained and experienced staff due, inter alia, to relatively low salary scales for technical staff. CEA does not have the human and financial resources to effectively carry out Environmental Impact Assessment (EIA), industrial licensing and inspection, small industries regulation, and response to pollution emergencies and enforcement. The project would strengthen MTEWA to assist development of policy and monitoring capabilities and mandate the regular updating of the NEAP, and to steer natural resource management policy and planning and coordination among all agencies (paras. 3.5-3.11). To complement the activities
 6 under this project, other donor agencies are currently planning to assist in strengthening the environmental management capacities of the line Ministries and provincial government institutions. 2.17 There has also been limited community involvement in the management of natural resources in Sri Lanka. The experience and lessons learned from other developing countries is that the 'top down approach" should be replaced by community-based institutional structures that not only fill the institutional vacuum but also cover part of the operational costs. This means identifying and promoting the use of environmental resources, in a manner that is not only sustainable, but that provides adequate financial returns to the users, thereby minimizing conflicts between growth and conservation objectives. The proposed Community Environmental Initiatives Facility (CEIF) is designed so that local needs, priorities, and capabilities are taken into consideration, and the local communities/non-governmental organizations (NGOs) are given full implementation responsibilities to ensure sustainable use of environmental resources (para. 3.15). D. INADEQUATE PUBLIC AWARENESS. MONITORING. AND COMMITMENT 2.18 Other factors that have contributed to environmental degradation in Sri Lanka are a lack of information, inadequate public awareness about environmental problems and their causes, and insufficient political will to address the problems. The public needs to be made aware that environmental degradation can threaten growth itself and its costs to society in the long run could be extremely high. Public awareness needs to be increased through mass media and education if sustainable and economically efficient use of land resources is to be practiced by the community. Mass education is also necessary if community participation is to play a greater role in resource management. Not only are general education and communication programs lacking in Sri Lanka, but specific information and data on the status of the environment in Sri Lanka are fragmented and inadequate. Institutional communication within Ministries is minimal. The need to establish an effective environmental information system, by setting up a network of information exchange, has been strongly expressed during the NEAP process. The project would fund environmental education and mass awareness programs with emphasis on the local level and the development of a national environmental monitoring information system to address this constraint (para. 3.10). E. ENVIRONMENTAL INSTITUTIONS 2.19 Two critical ministries from an environmental, multi-sectoral management perspective are the large and influential Ministry of Finance and Planning (MFP) and the relatively new MTEWA. Most of the line agencies in GOSL take an active role in some aspect of environmental management and, therefore, have a say in the implementation of environmental priorities through sectoral action. This section presents the main institutions involved in Sri Lanka's environmental management, with particular attention given to the multi-sectoral environmental entities. Central Policy Setting and Coordination 2.20 Ministry of Finance and Planning. MFP is responsible for policy formulation in all sectors. This includes the review and approval of all development projects, the public investment program, and the annual budget. MFP coordinates and monitors environmental programs and donor support for these programs through the National Environmental Steering Committee (NESC). 2.21 Ministry of Transport. Environment and Women's Affairs. MTEWA was established in 1994 as a Cabinet Ministry. It includes the 'Environment Division" within the Ministry of Transport and Women's Affairs and has authority over CEA. Although both MTEWA and CEA have made considerable progress in recent years, MTEWA still lacks the capacity and sectoral recognition to formulate environmental policies according to the country's economic development goals and policies. MTEWA also lacks the human and financial resources necessary to take a leading and more decisive role in
 7 environmental conservation and natural resource management in Sri Lanka. Its official strength of 12 professional positions does not presently provide this capacity, and the present structure of MTEWA is inadequate to meet all the needs and challenges related to environmental management and protection. Allocation and delineation of authority and responsibilities within MTEWA are not clear, and there is a need for a more functional organizational structure. Furthermore, MTEWA lacks a responsive administrative, accounting and information function to serve its own particular needs. 2.22 National Environmental Steering Committee. NESC was originally established as an ad hoc body to coordinate the NEAP. It is responsible for coordinating and monitoring all environmental initiatives, including donor assistance programs, and is co-chaired by the Secretaries of MFP and MTEWA. But NESC lacks the capacity and experts needed to develop national environmental policies and coordinate their implementation. In practice, it has functioned more as a forum for resolving operational issues and conflicts. 2.23 Secretaries' Committee for Environment and Development (SCED). The Cabinet has recently appointed a Senior Committee of Secretaries, chaired by the Secretary, MTEWA, to develop a national environmental policy. This committee would work closely with all agencies in preparing an environmental policy paper. It is expected to remain as an active committee that would not only address ad hoc environmental issues, as was done by NESC, but also address broader policy issues relating to economic development. Enforcement and Monitoring 2.24 Central Environmental Authority (CEAl. CEA, established in 1980, was originally the sole statutory body with environmental protection responsibility under the Basic Environment Law (#47/1980). Constrained by a vague mandate, weak government commitment, limited resources, and lack of specific environmental management tools and implementation authority, CEA's accomplishments during the first ten years were modest. Amendments to the Basic Environment Law enacted in 1988 designated industrial pollution control as CEA's priority mandate and assigned environmental licensing authority to the agency. A 1990 regulation equipped CEA with another potentially powerful tool, EIA, and EIA became a statutory requirement in 1993. CEA has delegated EIA review and approval responsibilities to 14 Project Approving Agencies (PAAs), and it helps these agencies process their EIA reports. 2.25 CEA has introduced an environmental licensing scheme (EPL) aimed at all polluting industries and projects, and helped to establish pollution mitigation regulations (1990) and a statutory requirement for EIAs (1993). CEA's other activities have included an inventory of imported chemicals; a review of existing legislative measures affecting the environment; environmental awareness programs in schools; an environmental volunteer service program; the production of teaching aides and educational materials; the establishment of an environmental library; and the presentation of seminars, workshops, radio, and TV programs on environmental issues. CEA participates in MEIP, water quality monitoring, air pollution monitoring for Colombo, environmental clearance of hotel projects, implementation of the Forestry Master Plan. etc. CEA's Legal Unit, with only two officers, is severely understaffed. 2.26 The broad and growing responsibilities of CEA are not matched by its human and financial resources. The inadequacy of existing staff levels (130 total staff positions, of which 51 are managerial, professional, or technical positions and the remainder are support positions) would be somewhat relieved by the addition of new positions under the project. Approval of the new positions is currently being processed by the Government. However, CEA has experienced difficulty in filling vacant posts due to a national shortage of appropriately qualified candidates and unattractive compensation levels that are inferior to those of comparable state bodies. Recently established donor-supported advanced degree programs in environmental disciplines are expected to relieve the shortage of qualified candidates within this decade, but the problem of unattractive compensation levels remains. In addition to unattractive compensation levels, other weaknesses of the incentive system include heavy weighting of length of service vs. merit criteria for promotion, severe wage compression, and desultory external supervision
 8 (para. 3.8). CEA has recently delegated some of its local regulatory functions to the Divisional Secretariats (DSs) (para. 2.29). Accelerated economic development, including rapid industrialization, is imposing increasing demands on the agency in the role of MTEWA's technical, regulatory, and implementing arm. Presently, CEA has no branches outside the capital city. CEA has, however, recently obtained GOSL approval to establish four Regional Offices, anticipating that there would eventually be one such office in each province. 2.27 A Corporate Plan prepared in 1991 for the period 1992-96 outlines priority objectives, strategies, and action plans for CEA. This plan proposes staff increases of about 70%, improvements in compensation packages, and a reorganization. Until recently, there has been little progress in implementing the Plan's recommendations, despite a 1992 review that identified CEA's long- and short- term objectives and priorities. This lack of progress has mainly been due to the high number of vacancies in CEA and consequent lack of implementation capacity. 2.28 While CEA expanded its EIA and licensing programs and gained valuable operational experience in these areas after 1990, it failed to articulate a strategic plan, adequately strengthen its technical credibility, or achieve visible successes in pollution control. With the shift of the policy-making role to MTEWA, CEA now functions more as a technical, executing, and regulatory arm of MTEWA. CEA is working closely and more effectively with MTEWA, and proposed new laws would strengthen CEA's ability, to carry out its designated role. 2.29 Provincial & Local Institutions. The 13th Amendment to the Constitution empowered nine Provincial Councils (PCs) and 308 DSs with stubstantial administrative responsibilities. Seven PCs with Chief Ministers and provincial ministries have been operating since 1989. Under the 1987 Constitution, environment is a partially devolved subject, and this permits the PCs to establish a Provincial Environmental Authority (PEA). However, only one province, Northwest Province, has enacted provincial environmental legislation and has a small PEA with limited capacity. The lack of involvement of the PCs, local authorities, and DSs in environmental management and protection is a shortcoming that would need to be addressed. While this first-phase project would not address regional institutional strengthening as a priority, it would nevertheless: (i) demonstrate PC involvement in environmental issues tlhrough thc pilot land management component (para. 4. 11); (ii) foster local authority involvement through the CEIF (para. 3.15); and (iii) coordinate with bilateral external agencies (e.g., Dutch and Norwegian assistance) that are involved in regional institutional strengthening. 2.30 Non-Governmental Organizations (NGOs) and Communities. There are reportedly more than 275 environmental NGOs in Sri Lanka. NGOs have been playing increasingly active roles in areas of operational implementation of environmental management as well as advocacy to raise awareness to environmental issues at the official and community levels. While most of these organizations are small in size and operate at the local level, there is an increasing number of national NGOs, with headquarters in Colombo. who receive significant support from external support agencies, mainly the Netherlands, Norway, Canada, and the USA. There is general appreciation in Sri Lanka that ED of MTEWA and the CEA are leading the rest of governmental agencies in their acceptance of NGO and community participation in the planning and implementation of development actions. This effort of GOSL-NGO collaboration has facilitated NGO influence in the formulation of the first and second NEAPs and has ensured NGO participation in the design of the present project. The project would further develop participation in overall environmental management by (i) formalizing NGO participation as a priority program of MTEWA (para. 3.5); (ii) including NGOs in the overall program of training and human resources development pursued by the project (para. 3.12); and (iii) promoting NGO implementation of environmental activities through the CEIF component (para. 3.16) and the pilot land management component (para. 4.11). 2.31 The Private Sector. To date, private sector participation in environmental management has been slower than NGO participation. While GOSL's stated policy is to encourage private-public partnerships in addressing environmental concerns, the actual mechanisms and significant benefits of such

However, the project would indirectly promote the role of the private sector through support to the contracting out of activities that are now done by the public sector (paras. 3.7, 3.8), policy action (para. 3.13), and inclusion of private-public partnerships initiatives under the CEIF component (para. 3.16). The National Environmental Action Plan 2.32 Sri Lanka became one of the first developing countries to elaborate, with IDA assistance, a National Environmental Action Plan (NEAP 1992-1996) in 1991. The NEAP included the major findings and recommendations of the National Conservation Strategy, the National Report to the United Nations Conference for Environment & Development (UNCED) and the World Bank-supported Environmental Action Plan of 1991. The plan is being carried out with the active support of the donor community and NGOs. The original plan was, however, a preliminary framework that defined the broad objectives, and priorities for environmental policies and programs. It fell short of making a critical assessment of the interaction between economic policies and environmental issues. GOSL felt that far more should and could be done to better incorporate sound environment management into the economic development process and that enough had changed since 1991 to warrant updating the NEAP. For these reasons, and as part of the preparation activities of the present project, GOSL updated the NEAP in 1994. The updated NEAP3 covers the period 1995-1998. Perhaps the single most significant aspect of the first revision of the NEAP is to attempt to articulate the relationships between the country's broad-based economic development strategies and the steps necessary to ensure environmentally sound development. 2.33 Three important premises were given to this effort. First, the updated NEAP has been developed with a highly participatory and collaborative process. Second, it is intended to be a 'living" document, which can be further updated and built upon in the future. Third, it provides a dynamic environmental policy foundation to obtain further financial support for programs designed to assist Sri Lanka's efforts to achieve environmentally sustainable development. 2.34 The updated NEAP. The updated NEAP provides a framework for interventions deemed necessary to safeguard the environment. It consists of six program areas: (i) strengthening institutions to coordinate environmental activities, developing policies and legislation and enforcing regulations; (ii) managing land and water resources; (iii) protecting forest and biodiversity; (iv) managing urban and industrial pollution; (v) protecting coastal and marine resources; and (vi) managing energy and mineral resources. The updated NEAP sets the stage for regular updating exercises to ensure that Sri Lanka follows a sustainable economic development path. 2.35 The updated NEAP has, however, several shortcomings. First, it has a short-term horizon. Second, it comprises several programs that are at different levels of maturity, some being merely identified, some being adequately prepared and qualified for instant support. Third, the plan falls short of defining priority actions within broad categories of problems, identifying appropriate policy instruments, and integrating environmental concerns more cost-effectively and consistently across economic sectors. Further analyses would be undertaken during the project period to refine some of the linkages and identify appropriate policy instruments in each program area (see para. 3.13). F. BENEFITS, JUSTIFICATION, AND RISKS Overall Project Benefits. 5.1 The proposed project is the initial 5-year phase of an expected long-term program that would assist Sri Lanka to meet its environmental challenges through proper institutional and policy changes, as well as through investments in environmental protection and conservation activities at the local level. Estimates during project preparation indicate that the annual costs of environmental degradation in just four areas (soil, forests, energy, and coastal resources) amount to more than 2.5% of Sri Lanka's GNP.'5 These are the costs of inaction and provide an indication of the potential benefits to be drawn from investments to address environmental problems. The order of magnitude of this degradation underscores the urgency of corrective actions. Policy actions, institutional strengthening and site-specific rehabilitation activities should provide substantial benefits. These benefits would extend well beyond the five-year project period. 5.2 The proposed project would put in place a process that would generate efficiency gains through the improved allocation of resources for sustainable development. This analysis applies only to the on-farm activities, which is about 10% of the total project costs, and directly estimates on-farm benefits through increased productivity. The analysis does not include externality benefits of on-farm activities nor the benefits and costs of off-farm activities within the microwatershed. Benefits to farmers are expected to accrue as a result of an increase in yields of existing crops due to improved land management practices such as vegetative contour barriers, bank stabilization through vegetative measures, and stone terracing. These practices result in the improvement of soil structure and improved retention of soil nutrients thereby increasing soil fertility. The 'With" project case includes the management practices with all other factor inputs remaining unchanged. Two farn models were analyzed 'With" and 'Without" these land management practices to assess the impact of these measures on soil fertility. The farm models show a substantial increase in farm income in the 'With" case due to introduction of these land management practices. The results of farm budget analysis are given in Annex 7, Tables A7.2- 7.4. The overall economic rate of return (ERR) of the proposed interventions to farmers in the pilot micro-watersheds is 16% in Model 1 and 28% in Model 2. The average weighted ERR is 24% (see Annex 7).

Sensitivity analysis was carried out which shows that the ERR is robust and not sensitive to delays in project benefits. For Model 1, a lag in benefits by two years would reduce ERR to 10%. whereas for Model 2, a lag in benefits by 2 years would reduce the ERR to 20%. The sensitivity analysis also shows that it is not sensitive to shortfalls in projected yields, hence decline in projected benefits. A decline in benefits by 40% would reduce the ERR to 11% for Model I and 22% for Model 2. 5.6 To test the sensitivity of component's ERRs to possible adverse outcomes, an analysis of switching values of costs and benefits was carried out. The results indicate that if benefits decline by 30% and 75% for Models 1 and 2, respectively, the ERR declines to 12% which is the opportunity cost of capital. Costs would have to increase by 50% and 290% for the Models 1 and 2 respectively for the ERR to decline to 12% (see Annex 7). Some expenditures introduced by the project would become part of GOSL's ongoing recurrent cost after project completion. In both ED and CEA, the budgetary impact is significant with current expenditures rising by 39% and 33%, respectively from 1996 to the end of the five-year project. However, the incremental recurrent cost, in 1995 constant prices, by the end of the project is only 0.2% of MTEWA's budgeted expenditures in 1995 (see Annex 7). The IDA credit would finance incremental costs on a declining basis, and it is expected that they would be compensated by the overall gain in economic efficiency (e.g. through pollution abatement) due to the institutional strengthening under the project. GOSL has also indicated a willingness to sustain the ED and CEA expenditures and activities after completion of the project. 5.8 Options for the enhancement of the fiscal sustainability of the project include the following measures: (a) overall fiscal adjustment would facilitate the government to engage in high priority areas, such as the environment, where it has its comparative advantage; and (b) a freeze on new hiring in the non-staff grades including positions currently unfilled would improve sustainability. However, stringent budgetary conditions are likely to prevail over the next few years, which suggest that additional measures are necessary to ensure fiscal sustainability. As part of the project, provision is made for technical assistance in the first project year to undertake a study of the license fee structure with a view to improving cost-recovery. The recommendations of this study would be jointly discussed by IDA and GOSL, and an action plan would be implemented (para. 3.8). Preliminary analysis indicates that modest increases in the current fee structure could offset the increased recurrent expenditure resulting from the project (see Annex 4, paras 23-24 and Annex 7, Table A7. 1). Risks 5.9 Human Resources. The institutional component of the project would largely depend in the longer term on addressing the underlying problems that have made it difficult to recruit and retain highly qualified staff. The problems of low compensation package for high-level civil servants and a high ratio of support to high-level staff are key issues to be addressed, and these are being taken up as a generic issue in the GOSL-Bank dialogue on public sector reform, and in the case of environmental institutions, under technical assistance provided under the project. A study undertaken in year 1 of the project would lead to the preparation and subsequent implementation of an action plan to provide better incentives systems to permit well-trained technical staff to be recruited and retained by CEA (para. 3.8). 5.10 Complexity of Stakeholder Composition. The policy agenda required for sustainable development needs to be defined with a view to arriving at a broad consensus among a widely diverse set of stakeholders. The project cuts across many sectors, and consensus building on enviromnental policy
 32 implementation among line agencies, NGOs, and communities is a complex task. Project design has attempted to reduce this risk in the following ways: (a) clearly defining the roles of MTEWA/ED and CEA in policy planning and enforcement, with line agencies still playing a major role in implementing sector strategies; (b) utilizing existing institutions rather than creating new ones; (c) encouraging beneficiary participation with long-term measures such as the establishment of an outreach MTEWA/ED staff position, and in the short term, using participatory mechanisms for the land and CEIF components; (d) undertaking studies in areas where there is a need to clarify the links between economy-wide and sector-wide policies and the environment; and (e) reviewing and updating annually the policy reform agenda with IDA and other donors. 5.11 Pilot Land Management Component. Two major risks in the land management component are: (a) that there could be delays in adoption of the soil conservation techniques by the farmers; and (b) productivity increases from improved soil practices may not be fully realized. These would be addressed by providing mass awareness campaigns and farmer education programs as well as evaluating the long-term sustainability of the land treatments. While such efforts have been made in neighboring Asian countries, the longer-term feasibility of such measures needs to be studied in greater depth in the hill country context of Sri Lanka. This would be addressed by providing for a baseline study and follow- up surveys over the life of the project, various demonstrations to test the technology, and by introducing a beneficiary participation approach. The proposed component represents a step in an important learning process and should generate important awareness of both the problems and possible solutions.

This project fits into the Bank Group's CAS as it would strengthen the institutional and policy framework for environmental management leading to cost-effective and fiscally sustainable improvement in selective areas of environmental policy making and enforcement that belong in the private sector, while promoting the contracting out of environmental services currently undertaken by the public sector. Some of the critical problems of environmental institutions in Sri Lanka (inadequate entry standards, low pay, and low morale) are issues that are not unique to this sector and will be addressed by the stand-alone civil service reform work that is at the heart of the CAS agenda on redefinition of the public sector. Soil erosion, deforestation, and other forms of watershed degradation endanger not only the future productivity of the agricultural uplands but also the sustainability of Sri Lanka's huge investment in hydropower, irrigation, and agricultural resettlement programs. This component is designed to use available land use information to identify heavily degraded soils in the Central Province and addresses on a pilot basis some of the most pressing problems with a view to finding approaches to minimize the adverse effects.

The objectives would be to (i) test and develop on a watershed basis suitable technologies for minimizing the extent of land degradation, thereby increasing agricultural productivity as well as reducing the risk of erosion and its associated on-farm and off-farm impacts; (ii) examine feasibility of participatory management of microwatersheds by the beneficiaries; (iii) define technical criteria and investment criteria useful in replicating watershed development activities in other hilly areas. 27. The pilot activities would be carried out in the hilly wet zone area of Sri Lanka's mid- and upper country of the Central Province. They would cover an area of about 10 representatives in microwatersheds (600 to 1,000 ha each) selected in sub-watersheds so as to cover a optimal range of micro-agroecological environment (with varying rainfall, slope and soil conditions). Project success criteria would, however, not be based on physical targets but on the development and adoption of appropriate site-specific strategies, techniques, and treatments to address land degradation. The project adopts a holistic approach and uses a participatory approach to involve both local populations and government officials from the planning stage through implementation and assessment of project results. The project would cover activities on the farmer's field, on communal lands, and on state lands within the microwatersheds. Key elements of the project strategy focus on stabilizing upland farming by increased control on resources. 28. The proposed on-farm treatments should ensure flexibility to tailor the proven treatments to the specific characteristics of the watersheds. Flexibility should include not only the adoption of site specific measures to cover a wide range of micro-ecological environments but also the prospect of a combination of, where appropriate and possible, both vegetative and limited engineering solutions. The proposed treatments would seek to combine affordable, simple, and replicable technologies with greater reliance on contour cultivation, in situ moisture conservation, and vegetative contour hedges/strips (porous barriers) with short-term income generating goals suitable to the small size of the average land holdings (under 1 ha per farm family). The range of interventions would incorporate elements of the Sloping Agricultural Land Technology (SALT) by encouraging the planting of leguminous shrubs, grasses (including vetiver), and tree crops along the bunds of existing terraces or along contours in unterraced lands. These soil stabilization and moisture retention treatments would complement mixed farming systems of food crops, fruit and timber tress, and estate crops. Farmers would be provided with technical advise and limited purchased inputs, with major emphasis being on proven labor intensive techniques and low-cost treatments, with the farmer contributing his labor as a major input. 29. Treatments on non-arable land (range lands, wastelands, degraded forests) and natural drainage's courses would include treatments such as vegetative fencing, stabilization through vegetative contour barriers, contour furrowing, diversion drains, gully control and bank stabilization through vegetative measures, storage, and management of runoff in natural depressions/partially dug out structures with low dams to promote the recharge of groundwater, and decongest blocked drainage lines. To support these works, the project would provide funds to meet the costs of land use mapping, land use planning, crop inputs, seedlings, vegetative and mechanical treatments, demonstration plots, mass awareness, training, vehicles, equipment, consultancy services, incremental staff, and operating costs.

Microcatchment planning. Microcatchment planning is the key element to interaction with local population. The building blocks of the MC plans are the village plans formulated through close interaction over problems and solutions in each of the MC villages. The time required to prepare the indicative MC plan would depend on the number of villages in the MC, but an average of one month is considered reasonable. After selection of the MC, which includes confirmation of local interest, the first step in the planning process entails the marshaling of existing information (data and maps). Sri Lanka is fortunate in having a GIS data base that provides a good basis for such planning. Active farmer's involvement and community participation regarding the planning and implementation of project actions is an essential feature of MC planning. Using a 'farmer centered-problem census, problem solving" (FC- PCPS),4 the MC planning process involves the following steps: (i) village discussions of problems and constraints and presentation of the menu of treatments provided for under the project, including cost sharing arrangements; (ii) village discussions of solutions and priorities (selections from the menu); (iii) preparation of draft village plans; (iv) village discussions of draft plans; and (v) finalization of an indicative MC plan aggregating the village plans. The FC-PCPS process is expected to ensure that the interventions respond to the perceived local needs and priorities and that a genuine commitment to, and responsibility for, the success of the project is generated. 41. The outcome of this interaction would be agreements on an 'Indicative MC Plan" summarizing and aggregating the analysis of available data; the results of the FC-PCPS process; the type, volume, and phasing of different treatments selected from the menu; and the extent of cost and benefit sharing for each investment. The budget for each microcatchment will obviously vary according to the population and site characteristics. Plans would be reviewed by the Provincial Director of Agriculture & Land Development. After approval, detailed implementation plans would be agreed upon with the participating community members and groups and commitments would be recorded in writing. 42. This annex presents the details of the rationale used in: (i) the economic and the fiscal analysis of the institutional strengthening and the Community Environmental Initiatives Facility (CEIF) components; and (ii) the cost-benefit analysis of the pilot land management component. The analysis is mainly qualitative as it is not possible to conduct a comprehensive benefit-cost analysis for an environmental project with institutional development as its main component. Additionally, most of the benefits are in the form of improved health and personal well-being and cannot be quantified precisely. The project through strengthening the institutions and improving the policy framework would enable better policy formulation and decision making on resource management issues. Through the CEIF, the project would provide for several conservation and environment projects at the local level that should assist in minimizing environmental degradation. Through measures for land management, on-farm agricultural productivity and incomes would increase, and outside the farm areas in the microwatersheds, the activities would reduce soil erosion and downstream sedimentation of reservoirs. It is also clear that without the project deterioration of the resource base would continue with adverse effects on overall productivity. 2. Institutional and Policy Component. The institutional and policy component does not lend itself to a quantifiable analysis in terms of applying conventional economic and financial rates of returns analysis. However, a brief qualitative description of the rationale for government involvement and expected economic costs and benefits is described below. The role of the 2overnment 3. The rationale for the project is the prevalence of externalities and associated institutional and market failures. Over the past decades, there has been a greater reliance on markets and less on the government intervention to promote economic development. However, environment is one area in which government should maintain a central role. At present, markets do not always accurately reflect the social value of the environment. First, markets are not working properly because it is difficult to enforce the rights to own or use 'public goods" in the environment. Second, open access to resources, such as water bodies, allows them to be exploited, and environmental effects are not recognized by the users. Third, the economy lacks information about environmental impacts with private firms having little incentive to provide accurate information regarding environmental externalities. 4. The role of the government is therefore, inter alia, to formulate environmental policy, increase awareness, enforce regulations, and design instruments to capture the environmental externalities. In the case of CEA's responsibilities there is, however, scope of contracting out some of its present responsibilities, such as the industry licensing and inspection functions. A study and a pilot program would be undertaken during the implementation period to analyze the scope for private sector participation. The project would also assist in the development of an NGO outreach program. 5. The proposed project would help Sri Lanka to meet its environmental challenges through important strengthening of the policy formulation process and institutional operational and regulatory changes. Environmental degradation is an emerging problem in Sri Lanka where more than 30% of yearly GDP is dependent on the country's natural resources, and as rapid industrialization, tourism and deforestation take their toll. Integration of environmental objectives would broaden development goals leading to a more sustainable development. The policy subcomponent would assist the government to review macro- and sector-wide policies with impacts on the environment. It would generally promote the

The institutional component would strengthen the focal entity for environmental policy, planning and coordination (MTEWA), and the institution responsible for regulatory and enforcement activities (CEA). As noted above, the public institutions will only be strengthened in those areas that cannot be performed by the private sector. Impact on recurrent cost. 6. Economic Analysis of the Pilot Land Manazement ComPonent 13. Pilot Land Management Component. Cost-benefit analysis was carried out only for the land management component. The purpose of the land management component is to: (i) test and develop, on a watershed basis, suitable technologies for minimizing the extent of land degradation, thereby increasing agricultural productivity and reducing associated on-farm and off-farm impacts; (ii) examine the feasibility of participatory management of the microwatersheds by the beneficiaries; and (iii) define technical criteria for replicating watershed development activities in the hilly areas. The primary benefits of the land management component include improved productivity and income through overall improvement of soil. Land management activities carried out on ten selected microwatersheds consists of on-farm and off-farm activities, and accounts for only 15% of total project costs. This analysis applies only to the on-farm activities, which is about 10% of the total project costs, and directly estimates on-farm benefits through increased productivity. The project benefits accruing to approximately 12,500 farm families and covering about one half of the total pilot area which is about 10,000 ha are expected to be significant. Most project benefits would emanate from the introduction of low-cost land management
 Annex 7 Page 5 of 7 practices such as vegetative contour barriers, stone terraces and other soil stabilization, and moisture retention practices. The most direct beneficiaries would be the rural poor, marginal, and small farmers. They would benefit from the additional output generated by the project at the farm level. Improved management of watersheds is, moreover, expected to have important off-farm benefits in the form of decreased sedimentation as well as a decrease in the risks associated with flooding and land slides. For example, the physical soil loss of the Upper Mahaweli catchment is estimated at 132,000 tons/year and the siltation level of the Polgolla reservoir in 1994 (only 14 years after commissioning) was estimated at 44% of capacity.2 The analysis does not include externality benefits of on-farm activities nor the benefits and costs of off-farm activities within the microwatershed, and to that extent the analysis is an underestimation of rate of return. 14. Assumptions. The underlying assumptions were employed in the analysis: (i) Prices. All values have been expressed in constant 1995 prices. All traded commodities were valued at import parity prices and all non-traded goods are based on domestic financial prices. Appropriate adjustments were made for margins, freight, handling, processing, and quality differentials. Non-traded outputs and inputs were expressed in border rupees through application of standard conversion factor (SCF) of 0.9. The wage rate for unskilled labor was assumed to be equal to the financial wage rate; (ii) Yields. Due to soil depletion, it is assumed that yields would decline by 1% per annum3 in the 'without" project case. Yields are assumed to decline by 10% in the year that the treatments are undertaken but are assumed to increase by 2% per annum thereafter; (iii) Project Life. A project life of twenty years was assumed for the analysis; and (iv) Investment Costs. After removing price contingencies, taxes, and duties, all investment costs have been included in the analysis. 15. Benefits to Farmers. A detailed analysis of farm benefits was carried out for the pilot area. Benefits to farmers are expected to accrue as a result of increase in yields of existing crops due to improved land management practices that result in improved retention of soil nutrients. To assess the component's on-farm benefits, two representative farm models were developed taking into account the major agroecological zones and cropping pattern. Both models use survey data to derive current farming practices, costs, and revenue. The 'With" project case includes land treatments such as vegetative contour hedges, lock and spill dams and stone terraces, and related costs and benefits that are compared with the 'Without" project situation. These treatments are currently being evaluated on an individual treatment basis by other donor-assisted projects, and the benefits are based on preliminary results. As the average farm size in the project area is less than one acre, these farm models are based on 1.0 acre mixed farm. Existing farming practices, crop mix, costs, and returns were based on survey information provided by MAL&F and confirmed by field observations and consultations with farmers. 16. The analysis of farm returns shows a substantial increase in income as a result of new technologies. By year 5, the incremental farm income for both farm models would increase on average by about Rs.5,548 (which is about 12% more than the 'Without" project case), and in year 10, the incremental income would be Rs.24,672 (which is about 63% more than the 'Without" project case). The average incomes of farmers adopting Model 1 would increase by 53% and double (104%) in farm Model 2. The increase in farm incomes reflects the high potential productivity of the proposed land management practices. The results of farm budget analysis (aggregate benefits over a period of 20 years) are given in Tables A7.3 -A7.5. 17. Economic Rate of Return. The financial costs and benefits and the Economic Rate of Return (ERR) are estimated using farm survey data. The net benefits are the overall increase in output as a result of the land management practices introduced that result in improved soil fertility. This is compared with the 'Without" project case of a decline in yields of 1% per year. Based on the farm income analysis, 2 Mahaweli Authority of Sri Lanka, HA&OM Division. Based on the assumptions, the overall economic rate of return of the proposed interventions to farmers in the pilot micro-watersheds is 16% in Model 1 and 28% in Model 2. The average weighted rate of return is 24%. 18. Sensitivity Analysis. Sensitivity analysis shows that the ERRs are robust and not sensitive to delays in project benefits or increases in project costs. Even a 30% increase in costs would result in a decline in the ERR's to 13% and 25% in Models 1 and 2, respectively. A lag in benefits by three years combined with a 20% increase in costs would reduce the ERRs to 10% and 19%, respectively. Tables A7.3 and A7.4 show a range of cost increase and lags in benefits and its effect on the ERRs. The sensitivity analysis also shows that it is not sensitive to shortfalls in projected yields, hence decline in projected benefits. A decline in benefits by 40% would reduce the ERRs to 11% for Model 1 and 22% for Model 2. To test the sensitivity of the component's ERRs to possible adverse outcomes, an analysis of switching values of costs and benefits was carried out. The results indicate that if benefits decline by 30% and 75% for Models 1 and 2, respectively, the ERR declines to 12% which is the opportunity cost of capital. Costs would have to increase by 50% and 290% for Models 1 and 2, respectively for the ERR to decline to 12%. doc.abstracts: The primary objective of the Environmental Action 1 Project is to help the Sri Lankan government strengthen its institutional and policy framework for environmental management within which the International Development Association and other donors will provide assistance. In particular, the project will: support restructuring the Environmental Division (ED) in the Ministry of Transport, Environment and Women's Affairs (MTEWA) for better policy planning and coordination; and strengthen the Central Environmental Authority (CEA) to better carry out its analytical, monitoring, and enforcement responsibilities; support ongoing efforts to integrate environmental considerations in the overall development planning process; and help the government take immediate remedial measures to reverse the trend of environmental degradation through pilot programs involving participatory approaches to environmental management. The project will comprise three major components: (1) Institutional Strengthening -restructuring ED within MTEWA to allow it to play a central role in environmental policy, planning and coordination nationally; restructuring and strengthening CEA by establishing and implementing a staff development program; enhancing the Industrial Licensing and Inspection Program; developing environmental codes of practice for small industries; improving EIA capacity, and strengthening the environmental information system; providing office and technical facilities to accommodate both ED and CEA; and studying linkages between sector and economy-wide policies and the environment including an annual review of the environmental implications of the Public Investment Program (PIP), and further updating the National Environmental Action Plan (NEAP). (2) Community Environmental Initiatives Facility (CEIF) -which will be established to finance well-planned environmental activities at the grass-roots level within the priority NEAP/PIP. CEIF will provide a mechanism for pooling resources -to which other donors could also contribute- and serve as a vehicle for private sector and NGO participation and for decentralizing environmental activities. (3) Pilot Land Management Component -which will entail pilot projects involving community participation in rehabilitating degraded lands.
